column1: The City of Canterbury-Bankstown is a local government area located in the Inner West and South Western region of Sydney
column3: Australia. The council was formed on 12 May 2016 from a merger of the City of Canterbury and the City of Bankstown
column4: after a review of local government in New South Wales by the state government.

column1: The Council comprises an area of 110.8 square kilometres (42.8 sq mi) and as at the 2016 census had a population of 346
column2: 302 making it the most populous local government area in Sydney.

column1: The inaugural Mayor of Canterbury-Bankstown is Khal Asfour
column2: the final Mayor of Bankstown and a member of the Labor Party

column1: == Suburbs in the local government area ==

The City of Canterbury Bankstown has a number of heritage-listed sites

column2: Corner of Marion and Edgar Street: Bankstown Bunker
Pine Street: Cooks River Sewage Aqueduct

column1: The City of Canterbury Bankstown was under the management of Administrator Richard Colley and Interim General Manager Matthew Stewart until elections were held on 9 September 2017 and the first meeting of the elected council on 26 September 2017. The Code of meeting practice for Bankstown City Council was adopted as the provisional code for the new council. The first meeting of the council was held at Bankstown Council Chambers on 24 May 2016. Jim Montague PSM
column3: was initially proclaimed as a Deputy General Manager of the new council
column4: but retired two weeks after the proclamation.

column1: The Council comprises fifteen Councillors elected proportionally
column2: with three Councillors elected in five wards. On 9 September 2017 the current council was elected for a fixed three-year term of office. The Mayor and Deputy Mayor are elected by the councillors for two-year and one-year terms respectively.
